JAMES W. CAMPBELL USN-Ret., 72, of Little Rock, passed away on Saturday, March 1, 2008. He was born April 10, 1935, in Lonoke, Ark., a son of the late James C. and Lyda Ashley Campbell. He was retired from the John L. McClellan Veteran's Administration Hospital. He was in the United States Marine Corps for six years, and retired from the United States Navy after an additional sixteen years of service. He was stationed in Da Nang, Vietnam, with the 3rd Battalion, 9th Marines, 3rd Marine Division, FMF. He received the Vietnam Service Medal, Republic of Vietnam Meritorious Unit Cross (Gallantry Cross with Palm), Combat Action Ribbon, Presidential Unit Citation, Marine Good Conduct, Republic of Vietnam Meritorious Unit Citation Civil Actions Color (First Class), Vietnam Expeditionary Medal, National Defense Service Medal and Good Conduct (Third Award). He was a lifetime member of DAV and was of the Baptist faith. He was also preceded in death by his daughter, Regina Roehm Campbell; brothers George Campbell and Norman Campbell; and his sister, Sue Pemberton.

He is survived by his loving wife of 49 years, Mary Dodd Campbell; son, Ashley Campbell and his wife, Dr. Cindy Hubach; granddaughters, Anna Campbell and Meredith Campbell all of Little Rock.

A funeral service will be held at 2 p.m., Wednesday, March 5, 2008, at Roller-Chenal Funeral Home Chapel (501) 224-8300. Interment will be at Pinecrest Memorial Park.

The family will receive friends from 6 until 8 p.m., Tuesday at the funeral home.

In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Disabled American Veterans, Building 65, Room 121, 2200 Fort Roots Drive, North Little Rock, Ark. 72114.

Online guestbook: www.rollerfuneralhomes.com/chenal.

EARL GENE GADBERRY, SR., 76, of Maumelle, passed away March 2,2008, at UAMS of acute leukemia. He was the son of Hope and Opal Gadberry of Monette, Ark. He was a faithful member of the Church of Christ, having served as deacon, educational director and bible school teacher. He graduated from Arkansas State University and was a graduate of numerous legal and insurance courses. He retired from Travelers Insurance Company after 36 years then spent ten years as an independent insurance adjuster. He was an avid sports fan and particularly loved baseball and fishing. He also served in the United States Air Force during the Korean Conflict.

He was beloved by his family and friends, and touched the lives of all who knew and loved him. One of his greatest joys in his life was being "papa" to his four grandsons.

He is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Elizabeth Gadberry; one daughter, Cindy Harben and husband David of Maumelle; one son, Earl Gene Gadberry, Jr., and wife Kathy of Maumelle; four grandsons, Dustin Harben of Little Rock, Adam Harben and wife Jessi of Little Rock, Earl Gene Gadberry III (Trey) and Jacob Gadberry of Maumelle. He is also survived by two sisters, Ellen Gibbons and Mary Ella Graham; one brother, Gerald Gadberry; and a host of other relatives and friends.

He was preceded in death by his parents and one brother, Billy Gadberry.

The funeral service will be at 10 a.m., Wednesday, March 5, 2008, at Roller-Chenal Funeral Home, (501) 224-8300, with Mr. Chuck Monan and Mr. Jeff Spry of Pleasant Valley Church of Christ officiating. Interment will be at Riverwood Memorial Gardens in Maumelle.

The family will receive friends from 6 until 8 p.m., Tuesday at the funeral home.

The family would like to say a special thanks to Dr. Doshi and the many other doctors and staff at UAMS for their loving care and support.

Memorials may be made to St. Jude Children's Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, Tenn. 38105.

Online guestbook: www.rollerfuneralhomes.com/chenal.

MAJOR ASHLEY J. GOLD, USAF Retired, 85, of Little Rock, passed away on Sunday, March 2, 2008. A B-17 navigator with the 8th Air Force during World War II, he was a graduate of Tulane Law School, a member of the Law Review and a prominent business owner in Shreveport, Louisiana. He was a long-time resident of Parkway Village.

He is survived by a son, Jonathan Gold; daughter, Lorna Marchand; grandchildren, Thomas Marchand and Rachel Marchand; sister, Dorothy Kaplan (Harold); and special friend, Carolyn Davis. He was preceded in death by his wife, Bettie Jo Mahan Gold.

Services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Pediatric Oncology Department of Arkansas Childrens Hospital.

Arrangements by Little Rock Funeral Home, 8801 Knoedl Ct., Little Rock, (501) 224-2200. You may sign Major Gold's online guestbook at www.littlerockfuneralhome.com.

JOHNIE CLIFFORD MCPHERSON, 75,of North Little Rock went to be with his Lord Sunday, March 2, 2008. He was born Aug. 31, 1932, in Coy, Ark., to Edgar L. and Donie Caldwell McPherson. He retired from 3M Co. after 28 years of service. He served in the National Guardfor 11 years. Johnie was a devoted, faithful member and deacon of Crystal Valley Baptist Church. He loved and served his church family faithfully.

He was preceded in death by his parents, Edgar L. and Donie Caldwell McPherson; three brothers, Ennis Lee, Buddy, Harold Ray McPherson and one sister, Juanita Higdon.

Johnie is survived by his wife of 23 years, Joy Jones McPherson of North Little Rock; two sons, Steven John McPherson and wife Chantal of West Memphis, Jerry Clifford McPherson and wife Tammy of Truman, Ark.; seven grandchildren, Matthew, Garrett, Megan, Steven, Chris, James and Dina McPherson; two great-grandchildren, Christian and Trinity McPherson; brother, Charles McPherson of Morgan, Ark.; three sisters, Velma Bailey of Bethany, Ill., Mary Dycus of Maumelle, Ark., Elizabeth and husband Tom Reeves, of Mountain Home; three sister in-laws, Eunice, Sue and Jean McPherson; one brother-in-law, Robert Higdon and a host of nieces, nephews, family and friends that will miss him very much.

Services will be at 1 p.m., Wednesday, March 5, 2008, at Crystal Valley Baptist Church, 5507 Crystal Hill Rd., North Little Rock, Ark. 72118. Interment will follow at Mayflower Cemetery. The family will receive friends from 6 - 8 p.m., Tuesday, at Roller-Owens Funeral Home (501) 791-7400.

The family would like to extend a special thanks to Dr. Diane Wilder and staff of Arkansas Cardiology and Arkansas Hospice. Memorials maybe made to Crystal Valley Baptist Church, 5507 Crystal Hill Rd., North Little Rock, Ark.

Online guest book www.rollerfuneralhomes.com/owens.

NIKITA KAY JOHNSON MILLER, 65, of Little Rock went home to be withher Lord and Savior Jesus Christ on Sunday, March 2, 2008, after a short battle with pancreatic cancer. She was born on Sept. 3, 1942, in Little Rock, Ark. She is the daughter of Klysta Moore Parlin and the late Charles D. Johnson. Her husband, Donald Miller, preceded her in death. At the age of 13, she lost her eyesight and attended the Arkansas School for the Blind. She received her B.S. degree from Arkansas State Teacher's College in Conway, (U.C.A.). She later received her Master's Degree from the University of Arkansas in Rehabilitation Teaching for the Visually Impaired. She worked for the Texas State Commission for the Blind for several years and for the Arkansas Division for the Blind. Before becoming a Supervisor, she was a Rehabilitation Teacher for the blind traveling several counties in the state teaching blind adults how to adapt to living skills and be independent. She was a Board Member of the Division Services for the Blind. She was a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. She was a blessing and an inspiration to her family and those who knew her. She loved the Lord and never complained about her physical problems, but was ready to go Home.

She is survived by two sons, Stephen Allen Shank and Edward Albert Shank (Marla) of Little Rock and one daughter, Maria Ellen Shank at Conway Development Center. Three grandchildren, Tiffany Miller (Tim Bennett), Dana Shank (Kevin Miller) and Dawna Monroe (Josh). Also survived by Klysta Parlin her mother and her sister Gertrude Beard (Kenneth), two nieces Betty Ann Horne (Jeff) of Marietta Ga., Vicki Beard Simmons (Kent) of Conway and one nephew Scott Beard (Leslie) of Little Rock and nine great nieces and nephews.

Memorials may be made to the Humane Society of Pulaski County, 14600 Colonel Glenn Road, Little Rock, Ark. 72210.

Memorial services will be on Wednesday, March 5th at 10 a.m. at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints Otter Creek Chapel, 13901 Quail Run Drive, Little Rock. Burial will follow at Pinecrest Memorial Park.

Arrangements made by Roller-Drummond Funeral Home, 10900 Interstate 30, Little Rock, Ark. (501) 455-5800.

ABE SKLAR ROSEN of Little Rock passed away March 2, 2008, at the ageof 90. He was the son of the late Ida Sklar Rosen and Jacob Rosen, and was born in Greenville, Miss., on Nov. 12, 1917. He is survived by his spouse of 64 years, Leatrice Block Rosen; three sons and their spouses: Bob and Jane Rosenof Little Rock, Dr. Rich Rosen and Millie Zweir of Amherst, Mass., and Dr. Ron and Nicki Rosen of Berea, Ky., seven grandchildren: Sam Block Rosen and wife Melanie of New York City, Dr. Christopher Charles Rosen and wife Dr. Sarah Lueke of Fayetteville, Ark., James Rosen of Pittsburgh, Pa., Richmond Rosen and wife Kim of Villa Hills, Ky., Alex Rosen and wife Amanda of Covington, Ky., Sara Rosen and Lyndia Rosen both of Amherst, Mass., two great-grandchildren, Benjamin of New York City and Oliver of Fayetteville, Ark.

Mr. Rosen graduated from high school in Drew, Miss., and received a B.S. degree in Business and Finance from Mississippi State University. He attended graduate school at Louisiana State University, where he held a teaching fellowship. He then secured a position with the Farm Security Administration in Little Rock. He was a 1st Lt. in the U.S. Army serving in the European Theatre during World War II. Following his return from the service, he joined Block Realty Company in 1946, and in 1948 he established Block Mortgage Company, Inc. In addition to operating the mortgage company, he started developing land and building houses with P. E. "Rip" Munnerlyn in 1953 and continued with Bill Bosley when Rip retired. This company was subsequently established under the name of A.S. Rosen and Associates, Inc. Over the years, some of the additions he participated in developing were: Pleasant View, Longlea, Overlook, Sheraton Park, Aspen Highlands, Rainwood, Glen Eagles, North Gate, Lindenwood, Richmond, Brennan, Garrett Glen, Rosemunn, Sanford, Yorkwood, and Cloverdale. His latest project was the development of Stonecreek. He was a past president of the Arkansas Mortgage Bankers Association, and served a term on the National Legislative Committee of the Mortgage Bankers Association. In March of 1986, the name of Block Mortgage Company, Inc., was changed to Rosen and Carroll Mortgage Company, Inc., and this company was subsequently sold to First Commercial Mortgage Company in December, 1986. In 1996, Mr. Rosen went back into the mortgage banking business with Jim Carroll when they formed The Carroll Mortgage Group. Mr. Rosen was a member of Temple B'nai Israel for 60 years and a former member of the board.

There will be a memorial funeral service held Friday March 7th, 2008 at the Temple B'nai Israel at 1 p.m. officiated by Rabbi Eugene Levy. A reception will follow at the Temple. Burial serviceswere private. Arrangements are under the direction of Ruebel Funeral Home, www.ruebelfuneralhome.com.

In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to The Storthz Religious School Fund at Temple B'nai Israel, 3700 Rodney Parham Road, Little Rock, Ark. 72212, or The Pulaski County Humane Society, 14600 Colonel Glenn Road, Little Rock, Ark. 72210 or your favorite charity.

CABOT - Terry Don Treadway, of Cabot, Arkansas, died March 2,2008, at 4:30 a.m. at his residence, at 34 years of age. He was born July 23, 1973, at the Blytheville Air Force Base Hospital. He graduated from Cabot High School in 1991, and attended college at UCA. He was a pitcher on the highschool baseball team, where he was an all-District pitcher, was all-State, and was selected for the State North All-star team for 1990. He was dearly loved, and will be missed by his family and many friends. He made instant friends with all whom he met, and was a constant practical joker. Terry, we know, left us too soon, but we also know that you are in heaven playing your practical jokes, making everyone laugh like you did us.

He is survived by his parents, Bob and Janice Treadway of Cabot; two sisters, Barbara Janosek and Connie Treadway, both of Omaha, Nebraska,

HOT SPRINGS - Martha Gene Farmere, age 83, of Hot Springs, died March 1, 2008, born in Hot Springs on Sept. 16, 1924.

Mrs. Farmere owned and operated the first Massage Therapy School in Arkansas. From 1959 to 1978, Mrs. Farmere was administrator of Libbey Memorial Physical Medicine Center. As a licensed physical therapy assistant and massage therapy instructor licensed by the Arkansas Board of Massage Therapy, Farmere was still an active board member of the Arkansas State Board of Massage.

After her resignation from the Libbey Memorial Physical Medicine Center, she was Executive Officer for the Hot Springs Board of Realtors for 15 years. She received the highest award from the National Association of Realtors for her effective and efficient leadership during her 14 years of service.

She is predeceased by her husband, Fred A. Farmere; her mother, Edna Lee Elliott Howe, both of Hot Springs; her father, William Warren Elliott of Columbia, South Carolina; her step-father, William (Bill) Howe; a great aunt, Lela J. Erwin of Hot Springs; and the father of her children, Earl S. Bowling of Columbus, Miss.

Mrs. Farmere is survived by two daughters, Kathleen Masterson Bryan, and husband, Jim, of Hot Springs, Martha Lee Byrd and husband, Mark of Ypsilanti, Mich.; five grandchildren, Brandon Lee Masterson and wife Sarah of Fayetteville, Anna Kathleen Smith of New Orleans, La., Jonathan, Andrew and Jacob Byrd of Ypsilanti, Mich., and two great-granddaughters, Keirston Masterson of New Orleans and Elizabeth Masterson of Fayetteville and one great-grandson, Trenton J. The body will be cremated under the direction of Gross Funeral Home with private burial services in Greenwood Cemetery.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Arkansas Hospice, 628 Malvern Avenue, Hot Springs, Ark. 71901.

MALVERN - Eunice Swafford Tate, age 96, of Malvern, died early Sundaymorning, March 2, 2008, at her home.

She was born in Ico, Ark. (Grant County) on Sept. 14, 1911, to the late Marvin and Sarah Drucilla Tabor Swafford.

Moving with her family to Malvern in 1921, she continued her primary education here and graduated from Malvern High School in 1931.

Eunice attended Southern State College (now Southern Arkansas University) in Magnolia for two years before receiving her B.S.E. degree from what is now the University of Central Arkansas in Conway.

She pursued her Master's degree for a time, but married and started her family instead.

She was the widow of the late J. Cecil Tate, to whom she was wed on June 8, 1941, in the First Methodist Church in Malvern, by her pastor, Dr. W. C. Watson.

Mr. Tate preceded her in death in January of 2000.

Eunice retired from the Malvern Public School System in 1972 after a lengthy career teaching Home Economics at Malvern High School.

A longtime member of First United Methodist Church, she attended the Wesleyan Sunday School Class, and was active in church Circles.

She loved to sew and to knit, was a wonderful cook, and loved to grow flowers. She is survived by two sons, John C. WHITE HALL - Dale Dady, Sr., 79, a resident of White Hall, passed awaySaturday, March 1, 2008, at Jefferson Regional Medical Center.

Born Oct. 7, 1928, in Bogart, Mo., he was a son of Clair and Belah Kennerly Dady.

Mr. Dady was reared and received his early education inMcEwen, Tenn., graduating from McEwen High School. After high school he worked for the railway. Later, he worked as a metric machinist in Detroit until entering the United States Air Force during the Korean Conflict. He served in England for three years and in Washington, D.C., for four months. He married Anne Mullock on June 20, 1953, in Manchester, England. After returning to the United States in 1954 he lived in Memphis where he attended the University of Tennessee School of Pharmacy in Memphis, graduating in 1958.

He moved to Pine Bluff in 1958, and went to work for Connery's Drug Store. In 1959 he bought Cole's Drug Store on Dollarway Road. In 1971 he built Dale's Drug Store. In 1973 he started Dale's Campers. In the 1960s he traveled the central and eastern United States racing his thoroughbred horses. Dale served his patients and friends until 1992, when Parkinson's Disease forced him to retire.

Mr. Dady was preceded in death by his parents, and three sisters.

Survivors include his wife, Anne Dady of White Hall; daughter, Dawn Clontz and husband Jim of northern Arkansas; son, Dale Dady, Jr. of White Hall; daughter, Sandra Sharp of Benton; son, Robert Dady and wife Sonya of White Hall; and sister, Elsie Wooden of California; seven grandchildren; three great-grandchildren.

DALLAS - John William Rhea Jr., beloved father, grandfather, greatgrandfather, and friend to many, passed away on Feb. 29, 2008. John was born on Oct. 14, 1918, in Texarkana, Ark. He was an avid tennis player, snow skier, dancer, and a colorful storyteller. His strong opinions will not be forgotten.John was well known and loved for his wit, his humor, his tremendous generosity, and his love of all people. He continued to enjoy salsa music long after his dancing days were over.

John grew up in Waldo, Ark., and attended Magnolia A&M (now Southern Arkansas University) in Magnolia, Ark. He then transferred to Louisiana State University where he received a Bachelor's degree in Petroleum Engineering in 1940. John's early professional experience with Standard Oil featured an assignment in the jungles of Colombia, South America. It was there that in 1943, John met and married Rosemary Thresher, his beloved wife.

In 1953 John joined Southeastern Drilling Company in Dallas, later known as SEDCO. As Senior VP in charge of Latin American Operations, he spent many years on the frontier of the oil services sector, negotiating contracts and overseeing field projects. He helped SEDCO eventually grow into the world's largest offshore drilling company. Through this work and his relationships with companies, in Japan and the PersianGulf, he earned many friends in the petroleum industry.

John was a longstanding member of Dallas Country Club and the Dallas Petroleum Club. He was a devoted member for 50 years of Highland Park United Methodist Church and was especially proud of having led the effort to preserve the original sanctuary at the church. John was a very proud member of the Dallas community, often referring to Dallas as the "Center of the Universe." He gave back to the community in many ways. He served as President of Goodwill Industries and also as President of the Trinity River Authority.

John was always eager to reach out to people in need. He never broadcast these gifts with fanfare, but his family would like to acknowledge his many contributions. These included: UT-Southwestern Medical Center Alzheimer's Research, Dallas Symphony Orchestra, Highland Park United Methodist Church, Creative Arts Center, Aspen Music Festival, Aspen Foundation, Aspen Art Museum, United Way, Parkland Hospital, University of Texas M.D. AndersonCancer Center, Southern Arkansas University (two annual scholarships) Louisiana State University, (John W. Rhea Jr. Endowed Professorship in Engineering).

John is survived by his beloved wife of 64 years, Rosemary; his children Tanyss Rhea Martula and her husband David of Hadley, Mass.; Bill Rhea and his wife Akemi of Dallas; Elena Rhea Cole and her husband Larry of The Colony; and Roberta Rhea of Tallahassee, Fla.; 14 grandchildren; one greatgrandchild; his brother, Frank Rhea of Golden, Colo.; many nieces and nephews; and innumerable friends whom he dearly treasured. The family wishes to thank John's loving caregivers: Gwen White, Mary Hubbard, Nora Alvis, and Alice Estes.

Visitation will be Monday, March 3, 2008, from 6-7:30 p.m. at Restland Funeral Home. Memorial services to celebrate John's life will be held on Tuesday, March 4, 2008 in the Main Sanctuary at Highland Park United Methodist Church, 3300 Mockingbird Lane, Dallas, Texas 75205 at 4 p.m., with Reverend Bill Smith officiating. Memorials may be made to: Southern Arkansas University at Magnolia General Scholarship Fund, 100 E. University, Magnolia, Ark. 71753-5000.
